text: I can answer regarding the royalty feature on

On Ethereum, royalties are platform dependent. That means that when you set royalties on rarible, but gets sold on Opensea, you don't get royalties. On NEAR, we developed the NFT standard with NEAR that means that royalties are forever engraved in the token and not platform dependent. You can share royalties with up to 20 people

text:
I don't think there should be any restrictions on what guild members want to do, or the tools that we use, across the entire ecosystem. But it's important to note that NxM stands for NEARxMusic, and that support for the activities the guild embarks on should add to the growth of NEAR in one form or another.

Bounties will be paid in NEAR, the current DAO for the guild is using Sputnik, which is part of the NEAR ecosystem. No one here needs to be exclusively tied to NEAR and of course, as the entire ecosystem grows, we are going to see more seamless interoperability, allowing us to do a whole lot more. So finding ways to integrate the tools we need as musicians are important. Like how we use Cryptovoxels for example.

That said, if a guild member was to request funding that doesn't benefit the guild (NEAR) it would be hard to justify awarding the funds. Hope that helps explain things a bit better.

Hey you guys gave me an idea to write an article about split royalties for artists because despite being in music for more than a decade I am still confused about it. You have publishing, mechanical, neighbouring rights etc and so on it can get really confusing for a new/young artist. messages.text:
Awesome! I wish I could do Thursday morning my week is slammed with festival planning and NFT launches but I’m Amber. I run nashville unsigned - digital magazine , label services , live events and community for independent artists. 

We are currently working on the live event space through festivals  

We’ve also started a minting and marketing company in the music space called Unsigned NFT. Focusing on independent artist NFT’s and a marketplace to find independent NFT’s. And a group on Facebook called NFT Music Community. Our vision is creating revenue streams that allow for these pro level indie artist to not only succeed but to flourish in their career and to also get educated and using crypto if they aren’t already. 


We are also working in the sync licensing space to hopefully run licensing through NFT’s and also a PRO for a niche genre. 

So a lot! Lol but our most exciting is the festival scene. We are doing musictree festival and the kickoff party for Bonnaroo this year as well. 

 we are just stoked to be in this community. Thanks for having us!

Hi all...something I keep getting asked by non-crypto musicians that I'm trying to onboard is how minting an NFT affects copyright. I've obviously had a look around...and read lots of different opinions...but it would be really useful to have a definitive answer. Anyone want to point me to it pls?....
...might be something for an onboarding bounty if someone wants to write it out...?

I believe an NFT artist’s work has two lives. That is for a C visual artist. 

The life on blockchain (NFTs) and the physical life (CDs, Prints, etc.)

And the person with the NFT doesn’t have a full ownership of the rights to the piece. Just an NFT life of that piece of work - for bragging rights or to hold as a form of value. 

This works in the visual art space and I think can translate in the audio space with little or no adjustments
I would suggest if you don't own the rights to the content you probably shouldn't sell it without including the other IP rights holders
Of course, when you sell the NFT you can assign IP to the buyer, but that's also tricky (SEC regulation)
It’s always great for audio artists under record labels to verify with their labels about putting out NFTs.
I would imagine independent labels who have deals in place with their artists could set up their collection/store and work in the splits that way.
Yeah! Exactly
That’s the best way to look at it.
I’m partnership with DAO RECORDS
Since they’ll be new in the space
there's a lot of flexibility
Providing information, technical know-how, platform and PR

That's my understanding...but there is some variation in opinion out there...
Can you share the other variant opinions on here?

I get it. Yeah I think that's something that traditionally people haven't worried too much about unless you're making enough money from it to not be under the radar. So unless you 'clear' the samples you're not really allowed to release and monetize the content, though people still do it. I think the same would apply for cover songs. You would probably need to negotiate all of that ahead of time.

Sorry for the stream of text, and I think  I might be preaching to the choir here, but I wrote this up, and I think it's important. Would love to hear everyone's thoughts. 

We’ve been asked a thousand times at IMT why we’re doing our debut album launch primarily in the crypto and NFT space. The short answer is that it allows us to connect directly to our fans. The long answer is more complicated. 

Since the early 2000s, and the beginnings of the streaming revolution- the birth of Spotify and places like it- musicians latched onto the promise of delivering their music to listeners across the world. Unfortunately, that came with a cost- mainly that EP and Album sales, which were the primary source of revenue before that point, went into the toilet as a result. Streaming services know that you need them in the current industry.

In order to make $1000 USD, you’d have to have a song streamed 333,333 times on Spotify. That’s not enough to live on as a musician unless you’re a big name. The way artists made this up was through more touring and more live shows. With Covid-19 ravaging the world this past year, that other source of income was and is completely devastated. Thankfully, we’ve been able to shift into the crypto and nft space with the help of Mango from Charged particles and other pioneers such as Dao Records and TokenSmart.

One event, one nft sale for us became the equivalent of millions of streams. It’s allowed us to continue being full-time NFT Musicians, and making music when most of the industry is shut down across the globe, when our friends and colleagues are struggling and out of work. This is only achievable by having fans invest in collectables directly from us while performing for an audience in the Metaverse. You don't need a middleman in the NFT Music space.

This is the future, and more musicians need to recognize it.
Correct 🙌🏿

I'm a bit of a contrarian though, so I think if people appreciate the music and the artist they will go to where they are to listen. As much as we feel the need to be on major streaming services, aren't we just perpetuating their use and preventing those true fans from enjoying Audio NFTs and streaming via Audius or Emanate? My main problem with Spotify and the gang is that you have no direct relationship to the listener, you only know what country they're from and how many streams (which when audited by Beatdapp showed under-reporting of 15-30%) Just some things to think of...

text:
while I understand the importance of funding for the creation of music for projects or touring, I feel like it's a bit outside of the current scope of the guild and the objectives of the 'hackathon' for which the current round of funding is allocated for.

We don't yet have the means to fund artists' studio time or touring, but it is something that we would like to see in the future, as I see the value in both your ideas.

If you have thoughts around projects that focus on creating a DAO/Initiative that other community members can participate in, or that deals with the current needs of NxM (Onboarding, Social Media, Documentation, Educational Material, Events..) and that bring value to all members or the NEAR ecosystem, then those are the type of proposals that have the most potential to be funded. 

That said, you can still follow the "
" and still have the ability to earn up to 100 N without the need for your proposal to pass.

text: Once you create your account, under -

- I recommend that you secure your account (Security & Recovery) with both "Seed Phrase" and "Email".

The Seed Phrase generated when you do this IS DIFFERENT from the one you used when you created your account (I just noticed this and might be why a few of you weren't able to get back in with your seed phrase). Make sure to save the NEW seed phrase in your important files and/or in your password manager!

Essentially if you own an NFT you can upload files for it. Limited to the name of the NFT + tokenId, for now, so it's 1-1.

You could take sub files though like [NFT + tokenId]-thumbnail.ext
It's pretty cool because I have no desire to manage user identity on my own infrastructure, db, server etc... GDPR etc... lame and lots of pestering...
ahhh cool, kinda like Mintbase with the store deployer NFT
yes similar but just a bit more web2 infra support for existing dapp that's walled by ownership of NFT

text: Beat Kitchen Challenge is a weekly beat making challenge, Production Studio and Live Streaming show that i host.  The show currently airs on Saturdays at 2pm Eastern Standard Time via my Twitch page and Instagram account.  Each week (Saturday) i provides a new download link containing a folder of five songs or a folder of sounds that participants are then asked to create beats of any genre from.  Participants are then given a week (from the Saturday the link is made available to following week’s Friday) to create their beats and then submit their beats to the Beat Kitchen email account by 12am Friday.  Beat submissions are then showcased during the Live stream.  The download link is made available via the Beat Kitchen Instagram page (link in page bio), or by becoming a member of the Beat Kitchen email mailing list. This challenge is open to everyone and anyone who is interested, no matter the level of production expertise.  Past beat and video submissions are available on the Soundcloud and Instagram page.

We will be getting our monthly funding for the NxM DAO via the Creatives DAO, which if I'm not mistaken should be where any of the creative DAO's get their funding. I think if there's a project in Muti that carries over into NxM we can look at supporting that from our side. messages.text: Yo 🚀🚀
hi mate, great and you?
Heya, did any of you already sell an NFT that included a physical version of the album/ep or a download link for example?

text: There have been a number of sales, not specifically from Mintbase though, that have had physical items attached. I know myself and

, I am asking to understand what would be the best way to do so. Like including a link that redirects to a shopping basked where thy physica item is already inncluded for example, or a form where buyer leaves his/her address and the album would be sent manually

messages.text: a link to a google form, or an email for them to send their address. mostly it's been items we've created ourselves, so we ship them off
okay. We were thinking redirecting to another website that is related could also be nice. thank you!

text: sorry last question, for the physical items, you would have shipping costs already included in the price in N I assume? Considering that shipping would be possible worldwide

messages.text: On mintbase you can add a website for any mint you create. Imo one of the simplest ways could be to add a site to the mint and use that site to manage the actually physical part.

Purchase of the NFT can be completely on chain, while the physical transfer completely off chain. If a user wants to receive the physical good, they just need to click the website link, fill or the form you have there to get in touch with you, and you can handle that however works best. As volumes of sales increase, a tool could be created, like a simple redeamer app like Nate was talking about recently.

NFT can be traded in the open market, once someone wants to redeem, they go back to the merchant and transact to "burn" (or in some way modify the NFT to make it clear it has been used) and then receive the physical good. 

Simplest way to go about this part imo is to simply have the NFT owner transfer the NFT back to your account to receive the physical good. You'd just have to ensure the correct person is getting the goods (ensure the same person who transferred you the NFT is the one you send the goods to.)

text: ah yeah true the website part, nice. i think actually in our case the person would keep NFT & physical piece. no need to return basically. we'd have several NFTs..ok will think about it. Thank you!

yeah, there's lots to think about. The main reason for taking back thr NFT is to ensure that you can keep track of how many physical goods are meant to be given out in relation to the NFTs minted. The way I think of this is when the NFT is sent, it can be bruned and a new NFT created. The NFT could be almnost exactly the same, but the first one could have [not redeemed] in the metadata somewhere, and then the NFT received after would have [redeemed] in the metadata.

messages.text: This way the buyer still gets to hold an NFT to commemorate the purchace, but cant use that same NFT to try and redeem more physical goods.

Also if they tried to resell the NFT on the marketplace it would be clear to the rest of the potential buyers that the NFT would not be redeemable because it already had been redeemed. the NFT would only be valueable for its on chain attributes instead of the ability to be exchanged for a physical good.

aaah I see. ok. I didn't think about that detail, good one. I was thinking if we would add somewhere that the first sale includes the physical part, then it can be resold without any issue regarding that.

The only issue there is that then people can't resell the NFT which is where a lot of value can come from as a creator. For example, the NFT may be traded 100 times before it gets redeemed. With a 10% royalty fee 😅, that pays for the asset without ever having sent anything out.

Also, the value of the piece may go up over time. For example, a pair of socks on etherium (unisocks) are worth over 100k 😅 (actually only 38k these days apparently). The tokens are traded constantly and only redeemed for socks when someone wants to make that transfer. A ton of economic activity is generated without anyone actually having to worry about the physical goods.

If you had 10 total goods and 9/10 sold for example, maybe the 10th one will stay as an NFT and never get redeemed, but it could still trade multiple times on the marketplace, which could still earn profit for the creator.
Only 23 more socks available and they are currently ~40k USD.

There are two NFTs involved for the trail. One for the track, one for the instruments ( synth ). When you own the track, you only pay one credit for the synth. I’m planning to keep the trail permanent, and also add more tracks to it.
So if you own the track you can always see the visualization?
If you own the track and the synth yes
If you only own the track then you still have to pay one credit for the synth when visiting the trails
It’s this way because in the editor you create tracks based on an instrument NFT. When you publish a track and some buys it, it becomes another NFT, with ties to the instrument NFT
The animation is made using threejs btw
We are open to collaboration ideas with anyone.  Feel free to contact if interested.

messages.text: is $32 not enough for gas fees to receive 50 Near into my metamask wallet?
anybody here?

We're not really the support for the bridge unfortunately, but like I mentioned above, you want to keep an eye on the ETH gas, as it changes constantly and might raise or lower the amonnt you need to pay to confirm a transaction. You can probably set the gas to the amount you can afford in the "advanced" setting (gwei) and wait for it to reach that level. Hope that helps!

I personally wish the process was easier. Maybe look into opening a Binance account (depending where you're located) or find someone in your country in one of the groups you can exchange with directly?

messages.text:
Jah Zone - Life Taste 

Jah Zone representing Limbe City brings the sound of the streets to his music, furthermore he is the first crypto artist from Cameroon. Heavily involved in education of people around him about NFT, NEAR and crypto space, which contributes to improving the lives of his closest friends and family. Jah started his music career when he was 8 years old, performing and singing live on the streets. He has decided to follow his musical talent, as his music gives people enjoyment - this is what motivates him to action. Jah Zone is 

“Life Taste” is the first studio album by Jah Zone. Music was made by producers, such as: Pepanic, Oboski, Paul Crans and JCBBeats. The atmosphere of “Life Taste” is oscillating between catchy ragga drums, dance melodies and overall is completed by the Hip-Hop vibe with original flow. Lyrics will take you to another world, seen by Jah Zone where you can experience his feelings and energy.

Full album will be available to unlock only for 7 NEAR after NFT purchase in DAOrecords’ shop on Mintbase. Only 30 copies will be minted.


Tracklist:

Life Taste (prod. By Pepanic) 
Twerk (prod. By Pepanic) 
FILO (prod. By Pepanic) 
Point And Kill (prod. By Pepanic) 
Flames (prod. By Pepanic) 
No Water No Neppa (prod. By Oboski) 
E Don Stay (prod. By Pepanic) 
E Don Change (prod. By Pepanic) 
My Way (prod. By Pepanic)
We Need Peace (prod. By JCBBeats)
Hustle (prod. By Paul Crans)
Will do, appreciate the support!
Thank you! I will do some more!
Such a great time. Glad I was able to make it!

▪️ NFT: Life Taste by Jah Zone
▪️ Minter:

“Life Taste” is the first studio album by Jah Zone. Music was made by producers, such as: Pepanic, Oboski, Paul Crans and JCBBeats. The atmosphere of “Life Taste” is oscillating between catchy ragga drums, dance melodies and overall is completed by the Hip-Hop vibe with original flow. Lyrics will take you to another world, seen by Jah Zone where you can experience his feelings and energy.

Tracklist:
Life Taste (prod. By Pepanic)
Twerk (prod. By Pepanic)
FILO (prod. By Pepanic)
Point And Kill (prod. By Pepanic)
Flames (prod. By Pepanic)
No Water No Neppa (prod. By Oboski)
E Don Stay (prod. By Pepanic)
E Don Change (prod. By Pepanic)

[10/17, 2:13 AM] Lebon: For a music artist, the lack of financial resources is a main obstacle to fulfill their career hopes. Covibes is a platform that facilitates music artists to sell their artistic projects and receive financial contributions directly from their fans, as well as crowdfunding for a specific verified project on the platform, such as working with a great producer, recording in a high-end music studio, crowdfunding for the production of an album or a track. 

By taking 5 minutes to complete this survey, you will understand how we can financially support you on your career path. Our goal is to help artists like you "fund your dreams with peace of mind".

text:
on Instagram for feature

▪️ NFT: Life Taste by Jah Zone
▪️ Minter:

“Life Taste” is the first studio album by Jah Zone. Music was made by producers, such as: Pepanic, Oboski, Paul Crans and JCBBeats. The atmosphere of “Life Taste” is oscillating between catchy ragga drums, dance melodies and overall is completed by the Hip-Hop vibe with original flow. Lyrics will take you to another world, seen by Jah Zone where you can experience his feelings and energy.

Tracklist:
Life Taste (prod. By Pepanic)
Twerk (prod. By Pepanic)
FILO (prod. By Pepanic)
Point And Kill (prod. By Pepanic)
Flames (prod. By Pepanic)
No Water No Neppa (prod. By Oboski)
E Don Stay (prod. By Pepanic)
E Don Change (prod. By Pepanic)
My Way (prod. By Pepanic)
We Need Peace (prod. By JCBBeats)
Hustle (prod. By Paul Crans)

Hello to you Mauvericks of the NxM guild, I have submitted a proposal for a 15 beat bounty of three different genres of music

This bounty would be for the sole purpose of artistes like me who are making Web3 transition and worry bout minting previously recorded songs due to copyright/royalty issues with producers and labels one was previously signed on

It would create an avenue for artistes like me to have personallyNFT songs of our ownwhich would be exclusively minted on the NxM store on mintbase..
Please feel free to comment your thoughts so we can progress together...
